results.raw_content:
5 ways LeBron James has made a huge impact off the court



Christian Alamodin

LeBron James is one of the best basketball players to ever step on the court. He's completely transformed the sport since his NBA debut in 2003, with similar players following in his footsteps since.

What makes LeBron James a very interesting player to see is how vocal and influential he is off the court as well.

There have been plenty of instances where the King showed everyone just how influential he can be. Here are five ways LeBron James made his presence felt throughout the league.

The financial boom he brings to cities

LeBron James is not just a player, but he is also a big brand. He's got the Midas touch. His talent and charisma make him one of the most sought-after athletes in the world, and companies are always at his door, looking to cash in on his brand.

In fact, cities that were in contention for the LeBron James Sweepstakes in 2018 weren't only anticipating his arrival in terms of his talent to dribble the ball.

It was revealed by Selena Hill of Black Enterprise that cities would feel a massive boost to their books, with New York getting a $1.7 billion boost to their economy if he made the move to the Big Apple.

Moreover, Fortune's Sarah Gray revealed that James's arrival to the City of Angels would be bringing up to $400,000,000 in profit for the city and create up to 3,000 jobs in the food industry, as establishments within a mile of Staples Center would pop up like mushrooms.

James knows that Black Lives Matter

Growing up under duress in Akron, OH, James knew how tough a rough background can be. He also understands that the system as it is now is not working fairly for people of color.

James has been a staunch critic of police brutality against African Americans and called for accountability on the police force. Moreover, he's not shy to tackle the racism he and his people are facing every day.

While he's been told by analysts to shut up and dribble, he's not afraid to use his privilege as an NBA superstar to bring up racial injustices.

â€œI know thereâ€™s a lot of tragic things happening in Charlottesville,â€ James says, per CNBC's Ruth Umoh. â€œI have this platform, and Iâ€™m somebody that has a voice of command, and the only way for us to get better as a society and for us to get better as people is love. And thatâ€™s the only way weâ€™re going to be able to conquer something as one.â€

James speaks up on national issues

James' opinions aren't limited to racial injustices. He also takes an active stand on national policy, not afraid to let his opinions on politics and pressing national issues be heard.

He's not afraid to call out people who he thinks are acting like a bum. He was very involved in the 2016 campaign of Democrat presidential candidate Hillary Clinton. He happily gave his opinion on any social issues that transcended the basketball court.

The greatest thing about LeBron James speaking up is that he made it okay for the rest of the league to let their opinions be known about social issues. He helped the NBA become one of the most socially involved professional sports league in the United States.

His continuous philanthropy to his native Ohio

LBJ may have traded the Cavalier wine for the Laker gold, but they can never take away the Akron out of the man. His charity, the LeBron James Family Foundation, is continuously involved in the community.

James commits a certain amount of his money in ensuring that the kids in the community get programs and initiatives that will help them grow up in a kinder and more holistic environment.

The biggest project of his foundation yet is the I PROMISE Institute.

James is a perfect role model for young kids to aspire to be

James made a few questionable basketball decisions in his career.

He's married to his high school sweetheart and has three kids with her. He's visible and involved in his children's lives, and his support for his son's blossoming basketball career is nothing short of adorable.

He doesn't forget his roots and is always involved in his hometown. He also shows his intelligence as he's not afraid to talk about politics. He's presented himself as a well-rounded person who has done a lot of right things. He's a perfect role model for kids to follow.

Christian Alamodin is a writer for ClutchPoints.

Mya Smiley is a student at the University of Akron thanks to an assist from LeBron James, and she is determined upon graduation to become a social worker that helps foster kids.

Her education and career path would not have been possible, the sophomore says, were it not for a scholarship and counseling that she received from the LeBron James Family Foundation. â€œHeâ€™s life-changing,â€ Smiley said.

For allÂ his accomplishments on the basketball courtÂ â€” four championships, 19 All-Star Game nominations and an imminent coronation as the NBAâ€™s all-time leading scorer â€” it is Jamesâ€™ ambitious pursuits off-the-court that may ultimately distinguish his legacy from other superstar athletesâ€™.

James co-founded a successfulÂ media and entertainment company, bought stakes in storiedÂ professional baseball and soccer franchisesÂ and, with a big assist from product endorsements, his net worth is estimated to have grown above $1 billion. The off-court achievement that James is most proud of, he says, is working to uplift the lives of people like Smiley in his hometown of Akron.

Many athletes have excelled in one or more of these areas. But few have done all of them as well as James, who is closing in on passingÂ Kareem Abdul-Jabbar for the NBAâ€™s career scoring record.

â€œHis goal, I believe, is to have 10% of his wealth go to causes and support communities, which is an amazing goal,â€ said Lisa Delpy Neirotti, a professor of sports management at George Washington University. â€œI would say heâ€™s maybe above and beyond others, just on that aspiration alone.â€

James is, by any measure, an overwhelming success. And he makes Smiley â€” one of the many people in Akron who have received financial support from his foundation â€” believe that she can be a success as well.

â€œIf I did not have the LeBron program, I probably wouldnâ€™t have ever gone to college. I would be living in a not-so-positive environment,â€ said the 19-year-old Smiley.

â€œHis ability to help peopleâ€™s futures,â€ she added, â€œis what makes LeBron a great person.â€

James, who entered the NBA straight after high school in 2003, planned early on to use his talents, fame â€” and, yes, his growing financial resources â€” to have on impact on the world beyond basketball.

â€œEven before I got into the NBA, I knew I wanted to find a way to give back to my community,â€ said James. Although James bounced from home to home during his childhood, and experienced financial insecurity for many of those years, he also was given enormous support from friends, neighbors and educators.

The LeBron James Family Foundation, founded in 2004, at first gained local attention by giving away bikes and backpacks. Then it began looking at after-school programs, with students scattered across several dozen schools, and eventually created a public school currently serving about 575 third through eighth graders. Today the school includes a family resource center that provides a wide-range of services to parents, including mental health, financial literacy, legal aid and GED courses.

Just down the street from the school, the foundation provides rent-free housing to as many as 16 different families â€” when needed â€” and it has plans to build 50 units of affordable housing.

â€œI couldnâ€™t have guessed how much it would grow,â€ James said in late January. â€œBut we got here by listening and responding to our community and what they need.â€

James has made over $400 million in NBA salary during his time with Cleveland, Miami and the Los Angeles Lakers. Another $100 million is on the way in the next 2-1/2 years or so.

James is a pitchman for Nike, GMC, AT&T and many more multinational companies. He owns a piece of the Boston Red Sox and Britainâ€™s Liverpool football club. His entertainment company, SpringHill â€” named after the modest apartment complex he grew up in â€” is valued at $725 million and has produced movies for HBO and Netflix.

â€œHeâ€™s been a brilliant example for millions of kids, especially kids with lesser opportunity and havenâ€™t had the same advantages as others,â€ San Antonio coach Gregg Popovich said in 2018, a sentiment heâ€™s repeated many times since. â€œThey see in this guy somebody who has consistently exhibited excellence in the workplace and gives them a voice and lets them know that you can speak about anything.â€

James puts so much focus on giving back to Akron because of the help people there gave to him and his family. â€œHeâ€™s never lost sight of that,â€ said Michele Campbell, the executive director of Jamesâ€™ foundation. â€œI think that keeps him grounded.â€

Just how down to earth â€œKing Jamesâ€ really was got called into question in 2010. Thatâ€™s when he went on television to announce that he was leaving Cleveland to play in Miami. Billed as â€œThe Decisionâ€ â€” and broadcast on ESPN â€” the live event was widely ripped as egotistical. But from Jamesâ€™ perspective, the broadcast raised around $4 million for charity, a fact that was largely overlooked.

Just a couple of years later, James would use his star power to help draw attention to a cause bigger than himself.

In the aftermath of the 2012 death of Trayvon Martin â€” a Black Florida teen who was wearing a hoodie when he was fatally shot by a neighborhood watch volunteer â€” James tweeted a photo of Heat players wearing hoodies and bowing their heads that included the hashtag â€œWeWantJustice.â€

In 2020, James helped lead the â€œMore Than A Voteâ€ movement, which included registration and early-vote drives and stressed the need for people â€” particularly Black voters â€” to get to the polls to fight disenfranchisement.

Also in 2020, in the aftermath of the Minneapolis police killing of George Floyd, James was one of the players calling for an end to racial inequality and police brutality.

â€œEverything I do,â€ James said late last year, â€œhas to have a purpose.â€

James has all the money and all the fame that he ever wanted or needed. His NBA records, including the scoring title, are going to last for a very long time.

As will his off-court endeavors.

â€œHis ability to help others and put others first is what makes him a great person,â€ Smiley said. â€œNot the baskets he shot.â€

LeBron James Sets Record Straight on Why He Walks Off Court Immediately After Games

Kristen Wong | Apr 8, 2025

Cameras tend to zero in on big-name athletes in the heat of a moment hoping to pick up a viralÃ‚Â reactionÃ¢Â€Â”a defeated look, a gleaming smirk, maybe even a temper tantrum.

Los Angeles Lakers star LeBron James has been subject to the lingering camera treatment more than a few times this season, including one postgame moment when James walked off the court immediately after a big win over the Dallas Mavericks back in February.

Yet, James insisted there was nothing unsportsmanlike about his behavior in a recent episode of the Mind the Game podcast with Steve Nash.

The 21-time All-Star shared that he does it after wins and losses and explained that he simply wants to head into the locker room as quickly as possible to mentally and physically prepare for the next game.

"It's funny, a lot of people see me walking off the court when it's like time left in the game," James said. "No matter if it's a loss or a win, the reason I'm doing it [is]... I gotta get to the locker room to start my process to get ready for the next game.

"I'll be sitting in the locker room, foot on an ice bag, ice bags on. I got my smoothie and my fruit, and I'm already getting to it right now. ... During a loss they was like, 'Oh, he's a poor sport.' Like, he's leaving the court. ... And then they start seeing me doing it during the wins and they was like, 'He's got no sportsmanship!'"

Every second counts for @KingJames. Ã°ÂŸÂ’ÂªÃ°ÂŸÂÂ¾Episode 2 is out now: https://t.co/pwk8BEr2F6 pic.twitter.com/ouYGmkl7AS

There are exceptions, of course, as James was recently seen dapping up Steph Curry and Jimmy Butler following the Lakers' loss to the Golden State Warriors last week. Even with The King's unmatched stamina and durability throughout his 22 years and counting in the league, it makes sense that sometimes he just wants to go home and rest his feet after a grueling game.
